user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of post_iterator:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
post_iterator (void *cls,
               enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
               const char *key,
               const char *filename,
               const char *content_type,
               const char *transfer_encoding,
               const char *data, uint64_t off, size_t size)
{
  struct Request *request = cls;
  struct Session *session = request->session;
  (void) kind;              /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) filename;          /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) content_type;      /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) transfer_encoding; /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */

  if (0 == strcmp ("DONE", key))
  {
    fprintf (stdout,
             "Session `%s' submitted `%s', `%s'\n",
             session->sid,
             session->value_1,
             session->value_2);
    return MHD_YES;
  }
  if (0 == strcmp ("v1", key))
  {
    if (off >= sizeof(session->value_1) - 1)
      return MHD_YES; /* Discard extra data */
    if (size + off >= sizeof(session->value_1))
      size = (size_t) (sizeof (session->value_1) - off - 1); /* crop extra data */
    memcpy (&session->value_1[off],
            data,
            size);
    session->value_1[size + off] = '\0';
    return MHD_YES;
  }
  if (0 == strcmp ("v2", key))
  {
    if (off >= sizeof(session->value_2) - 1)
      return MHD_YES; /* Discard extra data */
    if (size + off >= sizeof(session->value_2))
      size = (size_t) (sizeof (session->value_2) - off - 1); /* crop extra data */
    memcpy (&session->value_2[off],
            data,
            size);
    session->value_2[size + off] = '\0';
    return MHD_YES;
  }
  fprintf (stderr,
           "Unsupported form value `%s'\n",
           key);
  return MHD_YES;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no code fragments that require investigation for Rule 17.2. Reasons:
- The function post_iterator does not call itself anywhere (no direct recursive call).
- There are no calls via function pointers or indirect call sites in this snippet (no function-pointer dereference or invocation, no callbacks invoked). The only functions called are standard library/runtime calls (strcmp, fprintf, memcpy) which do not call user-defined post_iterator, so no indirect recursion is possible from them in this context.
- No global or static structures in this snippet hold function pointers that are invoked here; the cls parameter is only used as data (cast to struct Request*) and is not called.
- MHD_YES is an enum/constant return value, not a function call.

Given the above, there is no evidence of direct or indirect recursion in the provided code fragment, so no suspicious fragments to report for Rule 17.2.
